posts.name: Hugo_Klepsch
posts.cooked:
Hey everyone, Just wanted to share some info we’ve gathered on a potentially widespread issue.

If you look at the event log in the driver station, you can see that the first loop of the enabled robot takes several hundred milliseconds to complete:

450ms auto 1296×975 139 KB

450ms auto 1296×975 139 KB

450ms auto 1296×975 139 KB

The grey, green and blue dots at the top of the graph symbolize loops of the robot code. Grey is disabled, green is autonomous and blue is teleoperated. The top set of dots are robot code loops, and the bottom set of dots are loops reported by the driverstation software. When the driverstation dots go from grey to green, the robot code loops suddenly stop for 450ms.

The same first loop delay can be seen when teleop is enabled (this is the same match):

450ms teleop 1237×947 120 KB

450ms teleop 1237×947 120 KB

450ms teleop 1237×947 120 KB

Looking at the logs, we see that autonomousInit() is taking 260ms…

logs 1482×607 324 KB

logs 1482×607 324 KB

logs 1482×607 324 KB

…but autonomousInit() is very simple:

autonomousInit code 767×740 34.5 KB

autonomousInit code 767×740 34.5 KB

autonomousInit code 767×740 34.5 KB

We see this first loop delay every time the robot is enabled. We also see the same “ CAN Frame …” error. There doesn’t seem to be any fatal CAN wiring issue because there are no other CAN errors once enabled, and all devices continue to work normally. We can reproduce this on both our competition and practice robot, as well as with a empty templated robot code project.

You can see the magnitude of the first loop delay by zooming out to a wider period. You can see that the rest of auto does not have anywhere close to the same delay in loop times:

Auto, zoomed out 906×938 85.5 KB

Auto, zoomed out 906×938 85.5 KB

Auto, zoomed out 906×938 85.5 KB

We have profiled the JVM memory usage and found that the garbage collector runs approximately every 5-10 seconds. We don’t think this is the cause of the first loop delay.

We’re running the latest image on the roboRio 1, with a Java program. We use 13 Kraken motors on a CAN network provided by a CTRE CANivore.

Do you see this too?

link_counts.title: Every Auto Path Waits Half a Second?

posts.cooked: If you’re using pathplanner, don’t forget to run the warmup commands after configuring auto builder (which should happen on code start).

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: What makes this potentially widespread?  Have you found other teams with the same issue and data?

posts.name: Hugo_Klepsch
Carl Hauser
posts.cooked: Are you perhaps configuring your motors when you enable instead of when the robot code starts? Configuring typically takes a long time and is blocking.

posts.name: Hugo_Klepsch
posts.cooked: We do most motor configuration when the robot starts, however there are some settings that change between modes. For example, enabling brake mode on certain motors when the robot is enabled.

posts.name: Patrick McNaughton
posts.cooked:
We have had the same issue and assisted other teams with it, we found that scheduling the warmup command, and also disabling the default CTRE signal logger seemed to fix it. Are you having this issue at home or just at competition? If all else fails I would just add a small delay to the start of auto to prevent any negative effects of the overruns. See if anything on this post helps you out

Auto Init Overrun Programming

posts.name: Benjamin Hall
posts.cooked: Your disabledExit() is setting the neutral mode of the drivetrain, which is a blocking config operation on each of the four drive motors. That can easily take half a second.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics

posts.custom_user_title: Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics

posts.name: David Racovan
posts.cooked:
Us and 1076 had the same issue, with the same symptoms!

CTRE Signal Logger causes significant loop overruns after autonInit on FMS opened 04:37PM - 28 Mar 25 UTC Cryplo

CTRE Signal Logger causes significant loop overruns after autonInit on FMS opened 04:37PM - 28 Mar 25 UTC Cryplo

opened 04:37PM - 28 Mar 25 UTC Cryplo

opened 04:37PM - 28 Mar 25 UTC

Cryplo

1076 discovered this issue at St. Joseph WK2. Although our autonomous was workin … g at home, at competition on FMS we found that we were experiencing a significant loop overrun >800ms that caused our robot to behave unexpectedly. This overrun occurred roughly 1s into autonomous. There were high overruns after that too of about 250ms, but we believe that that is just because our auto-align is poorly written / expensive (there appeared to be a correlation between calling the auto-align command and the 250ms overruns). Between St. Joseph WK2 and Saline WK4, we were able to solve the issue. We turned off signal logging and also changed thread priority to real-time 10. Based on our limited testing in practice mode, if we keep the thread priority at real-time 10 but turn on signal logging, we experience the same large overrun, which leads us to believe that signal logging is the cause of the issue. In #programming-discussion of the FRC discord server, team 868 experienced a similar issue and was able to fix it by turning off signal logging. We talked with Daltz in the channel so they should already be aware of this issue.


**Loop Overrun Image:**
- https://media.discordapp.net/attachments/1337519185206444183/1355214705991614557/image.jpg?ex=67e81d8c&is=67e6cc0c&hm=a461e08ffa26b42e7e63be7adf66d3dff14565c86460841e58d91a8d6995d65f&=&format=webp&width=1745&height=1308

**Example Match Video of Behavior:**
- https://www.thebluealliance.com/match/2025misjo_qm43

**ChiefDelphi Threads:**
- https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/auto-init-overrun/494848
- https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/pathplanner-first-path-going-insane-help/494814
- https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/choreo-autonomous-loop-overruns/495597

**Discord Discussion:** 
- https://discord.com/channels/176186766946992128/368993897495527424/1355175663157383328

**Our Code (Week 2 and Week 4):**
- https://github.com/FRC1076/2025-Competition/releases/tag/Week2
- https://github.com/FRC1076/2025-Competition/releases/tag/Week4

link_counts.title: CTRE Signal Logger causes significant loop overruns after autonInit on FMS · Issue #110 · CrossTheRoadElec/Phoenix-Releases · GitHub

posts.name: Benjamin Hall
posts.cooked: In this case, I don’t see a SignalLogger auto-start message in the DS log on transition to enabled. And since this appears to be our generated swerve project (based on the C++ WaitForAll error), the SignalLogger should be started on robot construction, so that should be unrelated.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics

posts.custom_user_title: Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics

posts.name: Doug Kavner
posts.cooked:
bhall-ctre:

Your disabledExit() is setting the neutral mode of the drivetrain, which is a blocking config operation on each of the four drive motors.

I guarantee this is the issue. We had the same problem, made all the other fixes suggested in this thread to no avail and then discovered the blocking nature of setting brake mode ourselves. We now keep the motors in brake mode by default and we have a button mounted on the robot that switches all motors to coast mode for 10 seconds, with LED feedback, to allow us to move mechanisms manually when needed.

posts.name: Hugo_Klepsch
posts.cooked: Hey all, just to update, removing the brake mode commands completely removed the pause! Thanks
